Chapter on Divine Anomalies, Part 1
Zhu Fotu Cheng, Zhu Fotu Cheng 1 Zhu Fotu Cheng was a person from the Western Regions, originally surnamed Bo.
He left home at a young age, was pure and diligent in learning, and recited hundreds of thousands of words of sutras, well understanding the meaning of the texts.
Although he had not read the Confucian classics and histories of this land, when discussing and debating doubts and difficulties with scholars, they were all as if in the dark, unable to refute him.
He said:
I have visited famous teachers in KaÅ›mÄ«ra twice, and the Western Regions all call me one who has attained the Way.
In the fourth year of Yongjia era of Emperor Huai of Jin Dynasty.
He came to Luoyang, with the intention of spreading the great Dharma.

He was good at reciting divine spells and could control ghosts and spirits. By applying sesame oil mixed with rouge on his palms, he could see things a thousand miles away as if they were right in front of him. He could also make those who observe the precepts see this.
Moreover, by listening to the sound of the bell and speaking of events, there was nothing that did not have an effect.
He wanted to establish a temple in Luoyang, but when Liu Yao invaded and expelled the imperial court, the capital was in turmoil, and his plan to establish the temple was not realized.
He then hid in the wilderness to observe the changes in the world.
At that time, Shi Le camped in Gepei, and his army was known for its ferocity. Many monks were killed.
Shi Yezhi felt pity for the people and wanted to transform Shi Le with the Dharma. He then went to the military camp with his walking staff.
Guo HelÃ¼e, a great general of Shi Le, had long been a follower of Buddhism. Shi Yezhi stayed at HelÃ¼e's house.
HelÃ¼e followed him in receiving the five precepts and revered him as a disciple.
Later, when HelÃ¼e followed Shi Le in battle, he always predicted the outcome of the campaign.
Shi Le suspected him and asked:
I do not know that you have any extraordinary wisdom, yet you always know the good and bad of the military campaigns. Why is this?
HelÃ¼e said:
The general is born with divine martial prowess, and the mysterious spirits assist him.
There was a Å›ramaá¹‡a of extraordinary wisdom who said, The general will have a brief summer, and should become a teacher.
The minister's previous memorials were all his words.
Shi Le rejoiced and said:
It is a gift from Heaven.
He summoned Cheng and asked:
What spiritual efficacy does Buddhism have?
Cheng knew that Le did not understand the profound principles, and could only use the Way and techniques as evidence.
Therefore, he said:
Although the ultimate Way is far, one can also use proximate matters as proof.
He then took a ritual vessel, filled it with water, burned incense and chanted over it.
In a short while, blue lotus flowers grew, their radiant colors dazzling the eyes. Le believed in this.
Cheng then remonstrated, saying:
When the virtue and transformation of a ruler permeates the realm, then the four auspicious spirits appear.
When governance is corrupt and the Way declines,
then comets are seen in the sky.
The constant images are evident.
Blessings and misfortunes follow one's conduct.
This is the constant verification of ancient and modern times.
It is the clear admonition of the gods and humans.

Shi Le was very pleased and said, Those who were supposed to be executed, but were spared, are eighteen or nineteen out of ten. Thus, the Hu people in the Central Plains and the Jin people all began to believe in the Buddha.
At that time, there was a chronic illness that no one in the world could cure. Shi Le asked Shi Daoan to treat him, and he immediately recovered.
The secret and silent benefits he bestowed were innumerable.
When Shi Le returned to Hebei from Gepo, he passed through Fangtou.
The people of Fangtou wanted to attack the camp at night.
Shi Daoan told Shi Le, In a moment, there will be bandits coming. You should be informed.
Sure enough, it was as he said. They were prepared and did not lose.
Shi Le wanted to test Shi Daoan. At night, he put on armor, held a sword, and sat there. He sent someone to tell Shi Daoan, I don't know where the general is tonight.
When the messenger just arrived and had not yet spoken, Shi Daoan asked in return, Why is it so strict at night when there is no banditry?
Shi Le respected him even more.
Later, Shi Hu became angry and wanted to kill all the Daoists and harm Shi Dao'an.
Shi Dao'an then avoided going to He Liao's house and told his disciples:
If the general's messenger comes to ask about my whereabouts, tell him you do not know where I have gone.
The messenger soon arrived but could not find Shi Dao'an.
The messenger returned to report to Shi Hu.
Shi Hu.
was startled and said:
I had evil intentions towards the sage, and the sage has abandoned me.
He did not sleep all night, thinking of seeing Shi Dao'an.
Shi Dao'an knew that Shi Hu regretted it, and the next morning he went to see Shi Hu. Shi Hu said:
Where did you go last night?
Shi Dao'an said:
You were angry yesterday, so I temporarily avoided it.
Now that you have changed your mind, I dare to come.
Shi Hu laughed and said:
The Daoist is mistaken.
The water source for the moat of Xiangguo City was five li northwest of the city, under a circular altar. The water suddenly dried up.
Shi Le asked Fotudeng why he could bring water.
Fotudeng said:
Now I will command the dragon.
Le's personal name was Shi Long, and he thought Fotudeng was mocking him, so he replied:
It is precisely because the dragon cannot bring water that I am asking about it.
Fotudeng said:
This is a sincere statement, not a joke.
The source of a spring must have a divine dragon dwelling there.
Now if I go and command it, water will surely be obtained.
He then went with several disciples, including Dharma Master Shou, to the source of the spring.
The source had long been dry and cracked like a wagon track.
Those who followed him suspected that water would be difficult to obtain.
Fotudeng sat on a rope bed, burned frankincense, and chanted for several hundred words. After three days like this, the water flowed out in a trickle.
A small dragon about five or six inches long came out with the water.
The Daoist monks saw it and rushed to look at it. Fotudeng said:
The dragon is poisonous, do not look down on it.
After a while, the water rose greatly, filling the moats.
Sengqie sat quietly and sighed, saying:
Two days later, there will be a small person who will cause alarm in this area.
Soon after, in Xiangguo, there were two sons of Xuehe, who were both young and arrogant, and they teased a Xianbei slave.
The slave became angry, drew his blade, killed his younger brother, held his older brother in the room, and raised his knife to his heart.
If someone entered the room, he would immediately try to strike him.
He said to Xuehe:
Send me back to my country, and I will spare your son. Otherwise, we will die here together.
The inside and outside were alarmed, and no one did not go to see it.
Le then went to see it himself and said to Xuehe:
Sending the slave to save your son is indeed a good thing.
Once this law is opened, it will be harmful in the future.
You should be lenient. The country has a constant constitution. He ordered someone to take the slave, and the slave finally killed his son and died.
The Xianbei Duan Bo attacked Le, and his army was very strong.
Le was afraid and asked Cheng for advice. Cheng said:
Yesterday, the temple bell rang and said:
'Tomorrow at mealtime, Duan Bo will be captured.'
Le climbed the city wall to look at Bo's army, but did not see the front or rear.
He changed color and said:
When the earth tilts as the army marches, how can Bo be captured?
This is just comforting me with words.
He sent Kui An again to ask Cheng.
Cheng said:
Duan Bo has already been captured.
At that time, the hidden troops in the north of the city came out and encountered Bo, capturing him.
Cheng advised Le to pardon Bo and send him back to his homeland.
Le followed his advice and was able to use it to the end.
At that time, Liu Zhao had already died, and Zhao's cousin Yao usurped the throne, calling his era Guangchu.
In the eighth year of Guangchu, Yao sent his cousin, the false Prince of Zhongshan, Yue, to lead troops to attack Le.
Le sent Shi Hu to lead infantry and cavalry to resist him.
The great battle took place west of Luoyang, and Yue was defeated. He held Shiliangwu, with a tiger-like fence guarding it.
From the official temple, Cheng and his disciples went to the central temple.
As they entered the temple, he sighed and said:
Liu Yue is to be pitied!
His disciple Fajie asked the reason, and Cheng said:
Yesterday at the time of the pig, Yue has already been captured.
Sure enough, it was as he said.
By the eleventh year of Guangchu, Yao himself led his troops to attack Luoyang.
Le wanted to go himself to resist Yao, but his officials inside and outside all remonstrated.
Le asked Cheng about it.
Cheng said:
The sound of the wheel-top bell says:
'Xiuzhi tiliegang pugutan qutuodang.'
This is the language of the Jie people.
Xiuzhi means army;
tiliegang means to come out;
pugutan is the Hu position of Liu Yao;
qutuodang means to catch.
This means the army will come out and capture Yao.
At that time, Xu Guang heard this instruction from Cheng and earnestly advised Le to act accordingly.
Le then left his eldest son Shi Hong to guard Xiangguo together with Cheng, and himself led the central army on foot and horseback straight to Luoyang.
As soon as the two armies clashed, Yao's troops were greatly defeated.
Yao's horse got stuck in the water, and Shi Kan captured him alive and sent him to Le.
At that time, Cheng used something to smear his palm and observed it, seeing a large crowd, with one person bound in the middle, with red silk around his neck. At that time, he told Hong about it.
At that very moment, Yao was being captured alive.
After Yao was pacified, Le then usurped the title of King of Zhao and acted as emperor, changing the era name to Jianping.
This year was the fifth year of Xianhe in the Eastern Jin Dynasty.
After Le ascended the throne, his service to Cheng became even more devoted.
At that time, Shi Cong was about to rebel.
In that year, Cheng warned Le, saying:
This year, there are worms in the onions. If eaten, they will harm people. You should order the people not to eat onions.
Le Ban announced to the people within the borders, strictly forbidding them to eat onions.
In the eighth month, Shi Cong indeed fled.
Shi Le became even more respectful and would do anything only after consulting with him, calling him Great and Venerable Master.
Shi Hu had a son named Bin, whom Le later loved very much. Suddenly, the child fell seriously ill and died. It had been two days.
Le said:
I have heard that when a crown prince dies, Bian Que can revive him.
The Great and Venerable Master is a divine person of the state. You should go quickly and tell him. He will surely be able to bring blessings.
Then, Cheng took some willow branches and chanted spells over them. In a short while, the child was able to sit up, and soon he fully recovered.
From this, Le's many young sons were mostly raised in Buddhist temples.
Every year on the eighth day of the fourth month, Le would personally visit the temple to pour water over the Buddha statue and make vows for his children.
By the fourth year of Jianping (364), the weather was calm and windless, but the bell on top of the pagoda rang alone.
Sengming said to the assembly:
The sound of the bell says:
'The country will suffer a great loss within this year.'
In the seventh month of that year, Shi Le died.
His son Hong succeeded to the throne.
Soon, Shi Hu deposed Hong and established himself, moving the capital to Ye and calling it the founding year.
Shi Hu devoted himself to Sengming with even greater respect than Shi Le.
He then issued a decree, saying:
The Venerable is the great treasure of the country. He does not accept noble titles or high salary. If noble ranks and high salaries are not given, how can his virtue be honored?
From now on, he should wear brocade and ride in a decorated palanquin.
On the day of the court assembly, when the Venerable ascends the palace, all officials from the Chamberlain to the Left and below will assist in carrying the palanquin.
The Crown Prince and various princes will support him on the sides.
The master will chant 'Great Harmony,' and when he arrives, all the seated people will stand up to show their respect.
He also ordered Li Nong, the fake Minister of Works:
Inquire about the Crown Prince's health every morning and evening. The princes should visit him once every five days. This shows my respect.
At that time, Shi Huiri was staying at Zhong Temple in Ye City. He sent his disciple Fachang to the north to Xiangguo.
His disciple Fazuo was returning from Xiangguo. They met under Liangjicheng and stayed together for the night. They talked about their master in their carriage. They parted in the morning.
When Fazuo arrived, he first went to pay respects to Huiri.
Huiri laughed and said:
Last night, you and Fachang talked about your master in your carriage.
The ancient sages said:
If it is not called respect, it does not change even in the dark;
If it is not called caution, it does not slacken even when alone.
The dark and solitary are the foundation of respect and caution. Don't you understand?
Fazuo was startled and repented in shame.
Then the people of the country often said to each other:
Do not give rise to evil thoughts, the master knows you.
Wherever Shi Hui was, no one dared to spit, urinate, or defecate in his direction.
At that time, Prince Shi Sui had two sons in Xiangguo.
Shi Hui told Shi Sui:
The younger Amituo is about to fall ill. You should go and welcome him back.
Shi Sui immediately sent a messenger to check on him, and sure enough, he had fallen ill.
The great doctor Yin Teng and a foreign Daoist priest claimed to be able to cure him, but Shi Hui told his disciple Fayu:
Even if a sage were to appear, he would not be able to cure this illness, let alone these people.
After three days, he indeed died.
Shi Sui was intoxicated and planned to rebel, saying to his inner supporters:
The master has spiritual powers. If he finds out about our plot, we should eliminate him before he comes tomorrow.
Shi Hui was about to enter to pay respects to Shi Hu on the day of the full moon, and told his disciple Seng Hui:
Last night the celestial spirits called out to me, saying:
'If you enter tomorrow, do not pass by anyone on your way back.'
If I do anything wrong, you should stop me.
Every time Shi Huiyuan entered the palace, he would pass by Fu Jian.
Fu Jian knew that Shi Huiyuan was entering the palace, and he waited for him with great difficulty.
When Shi Huiyuan was about to ascend the southern terrace, the monk Hui pulled on his robe.
Shi Huiyuan said:
The matter cannot be stopped.
He sat down for a moment and then got up.
Fu Jian firmly tried to keep him, but he could not stay. The plot was thus changed.
Returning to the temple, he sighed and said:
The prince's rebellion is about to take shape.
It is difficult to speak of it, and difficult to endure.
He then used the matter to admonish Fu Jian in a roundabout way, but Fu Jian still did not understand.
Soon after, the matter was revealed, and only then did he realize Shi Huiyuan's words.
Later, Guo HelÃ¼e led troops to conquer the Qiang people in Chang'an, but fell into an ambush by the Qiang.
At that time, Shi Huiyuan was sitting in the hall.
His disciple Fachang was by his side.
Shi Huiyuan changed his expression and said:
Duke Guo is in trouble now.
He shouted:
The monks should chant and pray.
Shi Hu then asked, What is the reason for this?ğŸ”½Shi Hu then asked, What is the reason for this?
Shi Huiyan said, If you go southeast, you will survive. If you go in other directions, you will be in trouble.
He then performed a spell and made a vow.
After a while, he said, You will escape.

More than a month later, Shi Huai returned and said he had fallen into a Qiang ambush. When he was running southeast on horseback, he happened to meet someone from the camp pushing a horse to him, saying, You ride this horse, and I will ride yours. Whether we make it or not, it is up to fate.
Shi Huai obtained the horse and thus escaped.
When they checked the date and time, it was precisely when Shi Huiyan was performing the spell and making the vow.

The false Grand Minister of Education, Prince Yan of the Yan state, Shi Bin, was appointed as the Governor of Youzhou by Shi Hu. He gathered a group of violent people and used them to commit atrocities.
Shi Huiyan warned Shi Hu, saying, The celestial spirits said last night that you should quickly retrieve the horse. By autumn, it will become swollen and rotten.
The tiger did not understand this, so he ordered the collection of the horse and its return.
That autumn, someone slandered Bin to the tiger, and the tiger summoned Bin and whipped him three hundred times.
He killed the Qi clan that Bin had given birth to.
The tiger bent his bow and took an arrow, thinking that the punishment for Bin was too light, so the tiger personally killed five hundred people.
Zong admonished:
The mind cannot be indulged, death cannot be brought to life, and etiquette does not allow close killing, as it would hurt kindness.
How can there be a Son of Heaven personally carrying out punishments?
The tiger then stopped.
Later, the Jin army came out of Huai and Si, and the cities of Long and Bi were all invaded and threatened. The three directions reported an emergency, and people's emotions were disturbed.
The tiger became angry and said:
I have revered the Buddha and provided for the monks, yet I still attract foreign enemies. The Buddha has no spiritual power.
The next morning, when Zung entered early, the tiger asked Zung about the matter. Zung then admonished the tiger, saying:
In the past, the king was a great merchant leader who went to the Kaiyin Temple and once offered a great feast.
Among them were sixty arhats, and this insignificant body of mine was also present at this gathering.
At that time, a person who had attained the Way said to me:
'This host will exhaust his life and will receive a chicken body, and later become the king of the Jin land.'
Now that the king is the king, isn't this a blessing?
Border disputes and military threats are always a matter for the country.
Why do you resent and slander the Three Jewels and give rise to poisonous thoughts at night?
Then the tiger believed and understood, and knelt to apologize.
The tiger always asked Cheng:
What is the Buddha Dharma like?
Cheng said:
The Buddha Dharma does not kill.

As the ruler of the world, without punishment and killing there is no way to rectify and clear the country. Since I violate the precept against killing, even if I serve the Buddha, how can I obtain blessings?
Cheng said:
When emperors serve the Buddha, they should be respectful in their minds and obedient in their thoughts, promoting the Three Jewels, not being tyrannical, and not harming the innocent.
As for the wicked, ignorant, and unreliable who are not moved by transformation, those with crimes must be killed, and those with evil must be punished.
But only those who can be killed should be killed, and only those who can be punished should be punished.
If one is tyrannical and kills the innocent, even if one spends wealth on rituals, one cannot escape misfortune.
I hope Your Majesty will reduce desires and cultivate compassion, extending it to all, then the Buddha's teachings will flourish forever, and blessings and longevity will be far-reaching.
Although Hu could not fully comply, he still benefited greatly.
Hu's Minister of Education Zhang Li and Zhang Liang, whose families were wealthy and served the Buddha, each built a large pagoda.
Zong said to them:
Serving the Buddha is about being pure, tranquil, desireless, and compassionate.

Although the patron respectfully upheld the great Dharma, he was still greedy and stingy, hunting without restraint, accumulating without end. He would first receive the punishments of this world, so how could he hope for any blessings or rewards?
Li and the others were later all killed.
At that time, there was a long drought, from the first month to the sixth month. Shi Hu sent his prince to the west of Linzhang to pray for rain, but it did not rain for a long time.
Hu ordered Shi Le to perform the ritual himself. Two white dragons descended at the shrine.
On that day, there was a great rain covering thousands of li. That year, there was a great harvest.
The Rong and Di tribes, who had not known the Dharma before, heard of Shi Le's spiritual abilities and all bowed from afar. Without speaking, they were transformed.
Shi Le once sent a disciple to the Western Regions to buy incense.
After he left, Shi Le told the other disciples:
I see in my palm that the disciple who bought the incense is about to be captured and killed somewhere.
He then burned incense and made a vow to save him from afar.
The disciple returned later and said:
On a certain month and day, I was robbed by thieves at a certain place and was about to be killed. Suddenly I smelled a fragrance. The thieves, for no reason, were startled and said:
'The rescue troops have arrived.'
They abandoned me and fled.
At Linzhang, Hu repaired an old stupa and lacked a dew-catching basin.
Zong said:
Inside the city of Linzi, there is an ancient stupa of King AÅ›oka. Under the ground, there is a dew-catching basin and a Buddha image. Above it, the trees are lush. You can dig them up.
He then drew a diagram and gave it to the envoy.
Following his words, they dug and found the basin and image.
Hu often wanted to attack Yan.
Zong remonstrated, saying:
The national destiny of Yan has not yet ended. It is difficult to conquer them.
Hu attacked many times but suffered defeats. Only then did he believe Zong's warning.
Zong's Way of transforming the people was practiced. Many people followed Buddhism, all building temples and competing to leave home. The true and false were mixed, and many transgressions arose.
The emperor wrote a letter to the Secretariat, saying:
The Buddha is called the World-Honored One, and is worshipped by the state. Should people in the villages and alleys who have no rank be allowed to serve the Buddha or not?
Moreover, all Å›ramaá¹‡as should be lofty, pure, and upright, and be able to diligently practice in order to become Daoists.
Now there are many Å›ramaá¹‡as, some of whom are deceitful and avoid corvÃ©e labor. Many are not suitable. We should carefully investigate and discuss this matter.
Wang Du, the Secretariat Drafter, presented a memorial, saying:
When the Son of Heaven performs sacrifices to Heaven and Earth, and offers sacrifices to the myriad spirits, it is recorded in the sacrificial canon, and the ritual has a regular feast.
The Buddha came from the Western Regions, and is a deity of a foreign country. His merits do not benefit the people, and are not to be worshipped by the Son of Heaven and the Chinese people.
In the past, during the Han and Ming dynasties, he was first transmitted after the emperor had a dream.
Only people from the Western Regions were allowed to establish temples in the capital cities to worship their deity. The Chinese were not allowed to become monks.
The Wei dynasty inherited the system of the Han and also followed the previous rules.
Now that the Great Zhao has received the mandate, it will follow the old chapters. The customs of China and the barbarians are different, and the people and spirits are divided.
The outside does not agree with the inside, and the sacrifices are different. The customs of the remote Xia should not be mixed up.
The state can make a decision. Zhao people are all prohibited from going to temples to burn incense and pay homage, in order to follow the ritual.
The hundred officials, nobles, and commoners are all prohibited from doing so.
Those who violate it will be punished the same as those who engage in licentious sacrifices.
Those Zhao people who are monks will return to the attire of the four classes of people.
The false Minister of the Chancellery Wang Bo agreed with the proposal.
Hu wrote a letter saying:
The proposal by Du says:
The Buddha is a god of a foreign country, and it is not suitable for the Son of Heaven and the people of China to worship him.
I was born in the borderlands and am fortunate to be in charge of the mandate, ruling over the people of China.
As for sacrifices, I should also follow my original customs.
The Buddha is a barbarian god, and I should indeed worship him.
The establishment of rules depends on the superior's practice, setting an example for the world. If the matter is not flawed, why be constrained by the past?
Those barbarians of Yi and Zhao who abandon their licentious sacrifices and enjoy Buddhism, all are allowed to practice the Way.
Thus, those who are arrogant and violate the precepts take this as a warning.
In the Yellow River, turtles were not born before. Suddenly, one was obtained and presented to Hu.
Cheng saw it and sighed:
Huan Wen will enter the river soon.
Wen's courtesy name was Yuanzi, and later it was indeed as he said.
At that time, in Weixian, there was a vagrant, whose clan was unknown, who always wore hemp and cloth, begging in the market of Weixian.
At that time, people called him Hemp Robe.

His speech was extraordinary, and he appeared to have a mental illness. When he obtained rice and grain, he did not eat it but scattered it on the main road, saying he was feeding the heavenly horses.
The governor of Chaoxing, Ji Ba, captured him and sent him to Hu.
Before this, Cheng told Hu:
Two hundred miles east of the country, on a certain day of a certain month, an extraordinary person will be sent. Do not kill him.
As promised, he arrived.
The tiger spoke with him, and there was nothing different about his words, except that he said:
Your Majesty will end up in the Hall of One Pillar.
The tiger did not understand these words, so he ordered him to be sent to see Shi Hu.
Ma Ju said to Shi Hu:
In the past, in the Guanghe period, we met here.
In the You and Xu years, I received the profound order, and the end of the calendar has a period.
The golden li is exhausted in the loess, and the borderlands cannot follow it.
Driving away the traces of the spiritual period, there is no end to the excellence.
The descendants are luxuriant, and their arrival is accumulating.
When will the period of blessings be? I will always sigh about it.
Shi Hu said:
The turning of heaven and earth is extreme, and the decline will not be supported.
The nine trees have difficulty with water, and there is nothing that can be used to calm it.
Although the profound sages exist in the world, none can establish what must collapse.
I have long wandered in JambudvÄ«pa, troubled by many such afflictions.
Ascending to the clouds and mist, I meet with spiritual wanderings.
Sengqie and Mazhu talked all day, and no one could understand them.
There was a spy who only got these few words, and by calculation it seemed as if they were discussing events from hundreds of years ago.
Hu sent a relay horse to send him back to his original county.
Having already left the city, he said he could walk on foot, saying:
I have somewhere to pass by, so I cannot leave right away. You can wait for me at the Heikou Bridge.
The messenger ran away as he said,
but before he reached Heikou, Mazhu was already on the bridge.
Judging by his pace, it was as if he was flying.
Sengqie had a disciple named Daoxin, who was well-versed in both Buddhism and non-Buddhist teachings and was respected by Hu. He once talked about recluses.
Hu said to Daoxin:
There is Yang Ke, a subject of mine.
I have summoned him for over ten years, but he does not comply with the king's order.
So he went to see him, but he lay there arrogantly.
Although I am not virtuous, I rule over the myriad states. Wherever my carriage goes, the heavens boil and the earth surges.
Although I cannot make wood and stone bow their knees, how can a mere man be so arrogant?
In the past, when Taigong was in Qi, he first executed Huashi.
How could Taigong, the wise and sagacious one, have been mistaken?
The envoy replied:
In the past, Shun favored Puyi, Yu served Bocheng, Wei Shi served Ganmu, and the Han praised Zhou Dang. Guan Ning did not respond to the Cao family, and Huangfu did not submit to the Jin dynasty.
The two sages and four rulers shared their integrity together. They wanted to inspire greed and competition, and to elevate the pure wind.
I wish Your Majesty would follow the virtues of Shun and Yu, and not imitate Taigong's use of punishment.
When the ruler raises up, it must be recorded. How can you let the Zhao history be without a biography of the reclusive?
Hu was delighted by his words, and immediately sent Ke back to his dwelling place, and assigned ten families to provide for him.
He returned and reported this to Shi Huiyan.
Shi Huiyan smiled faintly and said:
What you say is good, but there is a hanging matter in the fate of Shi Hu.
Later, when the troops in Qinzhou rebelled, Shi Hu's disciples carried him westward to flee.
The Rong army pursued and captured him, and he was killed.
Once, Shi Hu was taking a nap and dreamed that a group of sheep carried fish coming from the northeast.
He woke up and asked Shi Daoan about it.
Shi Daoan said:
This is inauspicious. Will the Xianbei people have the Central Plains?
Later, the Murong clan indeed captured the capital.
Once, Shi Huiyan and Shi Hu ascended the main hall together.
Shi Huiyan suddenly exclaimed:
A disaster! Youzhou will suffer a fire disaster.
He then took some wine and sprinkled it.
After a while, he laughed and said:
The disaster has been averted.
Shi Hu sent someone to investigate Youzhou, who reported:
On that day, a fire started from the four gates. A black cloud came from the southwest, and a sudden rain extinguished the fire. The rain also had a slight alcoholic smell.
In the seventh month of the fourteenth year of the Tigris and War-Horse era, Shi Xuan and Shi Tao were about to kill each other.
Xuan came to the temple and sat with Cheng. A bell on the stupa rang alone.
Cheng said to Xuan:
Do you understand the sound of the bell?
The bell said, The barbarian will fall.
Xuan changed his expression and said:
What are these words?
Cheng falsely said:
The old barbarian practices the way but cannot live in the mountains without speaking.
Luxurious mats and fine clothes, aren't these falling?
Shi Tao arrived later.
Cheng stared at him for a long time.
Tao was frightened and asked Cheng, Cheng said:
I was wondering why you smelled of blood, so I was staring at you.
In the eighth month, Cheng had ten disciples fast in a separate room.
Cheng temporarily entered the Eastern Palace.
Shi Hu and Empress Du greeted Cheng, Cheng said:
There will be a thief from under your ribs within ten days. From the Buddha temple to the west and this palace to the east, there will be a flow of blood.
